number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												So, I picked up this game cause it was on sale a while back and decided "Why not?", and unlike most things I happen to get on a whim, this game happened to be a real treasure.  Starting off though, I HIGHLY recommend a Gamepad of sorts for this game. I can only imagine going through this game with a Keyboard would make one want to Chuck it out the window. If you do NOT have a Gamepad, some of the platforming will be quite difficult assuming you are too used to platforming like elements with a controller as I was. Also the jumping physics take some getting used to.Gameplay: The gameplay is as other people have called it "Metroidvania" Wheras the game is centered around these large ruins and have seperate areas within the ruins that define as "other levels" So, in a nut shell, you go around the ruins exploring, trying to figure out what purpose these ruins have or what mysteries you can unfold. The more you discover, the more items you unlock, thus allowing access to different areas of the ruins.Difficulty: Wow, there are parts in this game where it makes you wanna rage, but if you're like me, and enjoy a challenege. It's all in good fun. You cannot heal yourself by normal means, you have to either go to the hotspring outside the ruins, or collect enough green orbs to "Level up"      The puzzles in this game are quite clever ranging from block destrcution order to in game ciphers. Though there are puzzles as simple as placing a weight on a pedestal (or dias as called in this game) So, there is a large degree of puzzle difficulty variation in this game. (Protip: No hint is too small in this game)     The bosses.. holy crap. Their moveset may not be very extensive, but they are very unforgiving. There are 9 Main bosses in this game. The first one being... generally easy, but after that, it's no cakewalk. These bosses generally take a degree of skill to defeat. If you die, you have to start all the way back from your last quick save. It's usually not THAT far of a walk, though there is this one area where its just annoying.. gotta wait for elevators... and suicidal fish.. just a bad experience, but made one feel so accomplished after finally taking care of the foul boss for that victorious fanfare after defeating a boss.Music: The Music in this game is quite amazing I think. Not really much else to say.Storyline: Kind of non-existant untill about halfway through the game. There's slight lore on each area of the ruins, but once you reach that halfway mark and the lore starts to tie into each other, It becomes clear that there is MUCH more to the ruins than one could have initially thought of. I love it.  Category Rating   Gameplay 8   Soundtrack 9   Story 7   Difficulty 8   Overall 8-9 Overall, This game's got alot of good things going for it, music, story, memorable characters. It's difficulty and obscure puzzles may deter other gamers, but I enjoy the challenge. Pick up this game if you enjoy one as well!! You won't regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												A great Metroidvania platformer with a good sense of boss design and challenge but poor conveyance on puzzles.Presentation:This is a standard 16 bit 2D graphics. Nothing technically special but the environments are based off designs of various cultures throughout the world. Enemies are based off some form of mythology. The bosses start off fairly intimidating then you encounter a satanic goat.The sound track is great and there's even a sound test within the game. There's a variety of instruments used.Story:You play an archelogist named Lemeza who tries to search for his father in the La Mulana Ruins. The lore of this game is found on ancient tablets and you piece together them to learn the history of this place.Lemenza is a silent protagonist but there are other characters that offer hints to you adventure but are still somewhat funny. There's the old man obsessed with video games and like to tell obvious lies that are funny because how blunt it is. Too bad every other character is just exposition or shopkeepers telling you to buy something.Gameplay:The controls are fine with keyboard but platforming is like Castlevania I on NES.Jumping while moving gives you little control in manuvering your jump, but standing still and jumping will pause you in place for a second and then given full control of you jump. This isn't too much of a problem espcially once you get the double jump. The worst part of the platforming is when you walk off a ledge. You lose any form of movement until you reach the ground. This can be really annoying since you will climb up long vertical shafts.You gain a large number of powerups and weapons that will help you through La Mulana. Weapons have different attack arcs that can help you hit certain enemies much easilly but you will probably stick with the whip with its hidden upgrades or the axe which has an excellent attack arc.There's also sub weapons that provides a ranged attack that run on individual ammo system that can be switched around easilly once you find them. Weapons range from surikens to a very expensive but deadly pistol.There's usable items that only serve the purpose of opening certain areas or reading tablets. There is one however that is very overpowered and can break nearly every sub boss.The powerups are fairly simple to increased HP or movement speed, but none of them really change the game except the double jump powerup.The last items you collect is computer software. Most of these items are either hidden or can bought in the store. They do various things like giving a map of the area granted you have the map of the place, or translate stone tablets. There's also hidden software combinations that cause special changes but you really don't know what it did.The normal enemies are good in variety but some are designed just to make platforming really annoying. There's a medusa head like enemy that shoots arrows at you. They also cause the Lemeza to have knockback which can be very annoying when platforming.Most sub bosses you encounter can be dispatched with full HP with little strategy and the ones that can't be dispatched either test your paitence or requires actual skill. The main bosses are all pretty challening but lack variety of moves. Once you learn to dodge them while still able to deal damage, then they are no problem.Outside of fighting and platforming are puzzles and secrets throughout the entire place of La Mulana Ruins. Now this is the biggest strength and its biggest flaw. Be prepared to take notes on stone tablets because those will be hints to puzzles in the zone you are or in a completely different area. Some of the tablets are pretty clever. However, some are just vague. There's one that requires you to pause the game in certain places. Then find a hidden warp pipe that leads to 4 tablets that gives vague one word hints.The amount of times I had to use a walkthrough is too much. Add some breakable/fake walls, or special hidden locks that can only be opened by a randomized summon. The good news is that the most vague puzzles are optional and miss nothing too major. There's still some ungodly hidden secrets you need to solve.If this game did not have puzzles, then it was still be a great game, but some puzzles are pretty good. There's great skill based obstacles you have to go through. This game still is very hard when it comes to combat.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												This is my favorite game. This is my favorite game ever.The atmosphere in this game is incredible. Your adventure begins in a small 32-bit village just on the outskirts of the ruins. There are numerous expansive locations to explore in this game and with a clever warp system you're able to traverse them all without too much difficulty. Our protagonist, Lemeza Kosugi, starts off armed with nothing more than a whip and a laptop but by the conclusion is armed to the teeth with multiple weapon types, ancient artifacts and supernatural devices. The writing is clever and the dialogue can be very humorous. Your relationship with the plot can be as independent or amorous as you wish, however I would highly recommend getting involved because I found the histories and tales to be extremely compelling.Patience is recommended. This game is very difficult and some of the puzzles can be straight up obtuse. It's difficult to find out where to proceed next and what to do in the game, but every puzzle and path can be understood if you study your surroundings and use the resources available. Write down everything! You will not regret it.I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game so much I can't even really write a review. I'm just kinda talking about it. Buy it. Buy two copies.10 STARS 5/5 GOTYAlso ♥♥♥♥ Viy.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												One of the all-great retro platformers. La-Mulana derives it's inspiration from world mythology, Indiana Jones and most of all, old MSX games. As you progress in the game, the game expands greatly on all fronts. The deceptively simple game mechanics are built upon layer upon layer, the levels get larger and more complex, the bosses get bigger and badder, the mythology and lore gets more and more elaborate.. and knowing it will become necessary to solve some of the most fiendishly difficult puzzles ever seen in a platformer. Still, the game does not resort to unfairness. Every challenge is surmountable, no enemy is invulnerable, and every puzzle has a hint somewhere. At least, until the mythical Hell Temple. But then again, that place is designed for people who want to prevail against all odds. Everyone else can expect 30ish ours of best platforming that you can hope to get.

												I never got into the retro platformers, the retro games that made it so your weapon would have windup time, the ones that made it so you couldn't change the trajectory of your jumps while you're in the air, the very same games that made it so that each time an enemy touched you, you'd bounced back (sometimes into a pit). Much like Castlevania 2, La-Mulana is full of cryptic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like kneeling at a foot of a certain giant, jumping into a death pit to retrieve a chest, or putting monsters in place of walls in order to discourage you to go further and come back later.La-Mulana embodies all of that retro gaming ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and I love it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I prefer metroidvania's in comparison to most other games. There's the feeling of exploration that you don't get from other genres, an air of freedom that's restricted only by your equipment and skill, the challenge of reaching something new that's mere inches over the tower of angry crazed monstrocities that haven't tasted food in centuries, just waiting for you to slip... It's amazing.La Mulana definitely met what I was looking for. It's a scarilly difficult game, but it's fantastic. If you're willing to brave the countless monsters lurking around the ruins, and smart enough to outwit the builders of these crazy traps and puzzles, this game is for you. There's treasure to be found, people to help, and a mess of bosses and sub-bosses that will have you rattling the controller in rage... in a good way. The game is beyond the simple word "challenging", which is flung around too often these days.Be warned though, brute force is NOT the answer to the majority of puzzles. You have to be smart with this game. Bosses themselves are a puzzle of what is safe, and what... isn't. And believe me, if you make a mistake with bosses, the all too common game over screen should be enough to tell you to try something else. If in doubt, look to the manual on the website. If that's not enough, there's no shame in looking to a guide. This game, in a few cases, demands it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												La-Mulana focuses heavily on riddles and exploring inside a gigantic ruin. Some of these puzzles can be quite difficult to solve, but then you really feel you accomplished something. But even if you feel stuck, just go to another area, as many parts of the ruins can be accessed from the beginning. Others can be reached by obtaining certain items.There's a lot of different items, main and sub weapons to be found, each serving a certain purpose. So this gets elevated to a Metroidvania-style game.You even do not have to fight the bosses in a fixed order to progress. As for those boss battles, these are varied as well: There are stationary ones, in one fight you ride a track down in a mine-cart, while the foe follows you.Awesome.My only gripe in the game is some very obscure hints for certain puzzles. You probably might have to look up somewhere or trying out a lot there - but be assured, there so much to do in the game, You will never feel bad, if you 'cheated' after you clocked so many hours into the game already. Just check that thing in a suspicious room further (or go somewhere else, as stated above) and move on your own.The controls themselves are solid and work as intended. Only jumping down below properly needs some practice first. Lemeza falls straight down, if he doesn't jump from a cliff, unable to change direction. Luckily there is no fall damage and many regular enemies only do little damage, except for some sub and main bosses.Take a hop before jumping on platforms below you - and you can move Lemeza in mid-air. Required for certain puzzles and just being a small hint.I play the game with a keyboard by the way, while the game has full controller support, including XBOX360 support as in the dscription, and there's no problem with controlling that way as well.The Graphics are really well done. They are stretched in fullscreen, the aspect ratio is mantainted properly. In widescreen formats the black bars can be decorated with murals and other images by going into the Options menu - which is a nice touch. Each ruin is vastly different, many background objects and statues are unique (and often required to be examined further by the game). There's even a hidden area, where you explore some of the original areas with the MSX-style graphics from the 2005 version.Music and sound are nicely done as well. While the tracks might repeat too quickly, many of the areas (in my case, e. g. the Temple of Moonlight) have catchy background music, some more decent, others being more dominant. For anyone who likes videogame music, this might be just right. The sound effects help you, be it a breakable wall which makes a certain crumble noise if struck by (certain) weapons, different tunes whenever you fail or solve a puzzle and other effects.If you don't mind the difficulty at times and love either cool boss battles and some brain-teasing puzzles, get this game ASAP. It's worth every penny, especially at that bargain in this sale.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
One fool believed, in his foolishness, that he was a wise man. The fool flaunted his shallow wisdom and made decisions with a narrow mind. He proceeded to the right without hesitation.  Another fool possessed wisdom, but his knowledge led him to believe he was a fool. A fool who smothers himself without first considering the situation. He went with the flow, and proceeded to the left.One can only hope that a true wise man stands here now. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------La-Mulana is not for the faint of heart or weak of mind. This is NOT a game where you can grind until you're strong enough to win. This is NOT a game where you can skip the lore and expect to succeed. And this is most certainly NOT a game where you can expect an easy victory just because you looked up the puzzle solutions online.Despite what my Steam records say, I've beaten this game twice now. (First the original, then a non-Steam release of this remake.) And neither time was easy in the slightest. You want fun? Play this. You want bland tedium that will atrophy your brain? Play your Call of Warbattles or Flappy Crush.La-Mulana is more than a video game; It's a test of character.(Soapboxing aside, I have to point out that the Linux version seems kinda janky. Just a warning.)--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Those who do not listen, do not make light of the words of others. To come so far, blinded by pride at thine own powers... thou art a true fool. A fool deserves naught but death.

												this game is absolutely NOT for everyone. For example, a little over 80% of the people who bought this game can not figure out how to enter the ruins from the starting village! It is a puzzle based game mostly, and not the usual kind of puzzle either, the basis is usually to obtain a very hard to understand hint then apply it to a part of the ruins. For example, you begin the game with an inability to look at written text, so you have to figure out how to spend the money you have. You are expected to look at all the shop’s wares in the village and then purchase a portable scanner for your laptop. Another portion of this games puzzles is looking for places to apply game mechanics. Many times, a suspicious looking block can be broken to reveal treasure, or pushed out of the way, or can be walked through. Attacking certain things will be punished in the ruins though, so one should always be cautious.Many people also have a problem with the way the controls are: the keyboard control scheme may take some getting used to because the menu, pause, and movement keys can not be rebound (in other words- If you like WASD, too bad). Some have a bigger problem with the way the character moves-If you run then jump you will continue to in the direction you were going in a semi-adjustable arc, and if you walk off of a precipice will fall directly down. The only way to have control in mid air is to jump while standing still. You will then have control on the way down.the bosses are hard. So hard that unless you have certain items you will fail endlessly (or be very lucky, or spend a total of twenty-seven minutes between each attack you make dodging). you would have a easier time Beating Final Fantasy XII Blind on a low level You, see, LA-MULANA is like an avocado, it is a rich oily superfood, unique among most other fruits, but also has a taste that many find off-putting, or love. Even if you are not a fan of this game, if you play two and three quarter hours into the game you will see that it is a game polished and slaved over for the twelve years that it was.but sad to say as for me I would find it more fun drinking Gasoline, then jumping head-long into a cactus, having my friend set the cactus on fire, pour and rub salt on my wounds then after I'm all healed up Pay a Wizard to turn me into a goat send me to Iraq get violated by a local, then die from bloodloss  if this game was made by Nintendo they would have to litteraly have to get you sign a waiver so you would not Sue there asses this game is not even possiblewatch a video walkthrough step by step is my recommendation

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												IN SHORT: A very difficult game in the tradition of NES Metroid and Castlevania.Within the last year or so I learned the term "Metroidvania" and it seems like it was made for this game.  Gameplay reminds me a lot of the original Metroid, and then you're whipping skeletons just like Castlevania.I guess I was warned, but this is a hard game.  As if fighting your way through the ruins wasn't hard enough already there are hidden booby traps (frustrating, but adds a fun new element as well).I love the mix of cultural artifacts from around the world you see, and I like the story of the Mother Goddess who created the Earthly races in hopes they could return her to the heavens--and who periodically kills them off when they anger her.You find lots of clues on stone tablets (which may apply to something you'll find in a whole different area).  In theory it'd be fun to piece together the story like this, but I've found them more difficult to understand and sort of generic sounding (this is probably do in part to the translation from Japanese).I've made some progress (defeated one boss) and am hoping I can get past the difficulty factor and really get into this game, but it's possible I might give up.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Some warnings up-front: this game can be hard to get into.  The controls aren't explained well initially, and it takes time to get a feel for the platforming mechanics, which are fairly idiosyncratic.  It's not an easy game either; it pulls very few punches and is much stingier than most modern games about checkpoint placement and health recovery.  There are also several fairly tough puzzles that require some creative interpretation of the sometimes-badly-translated hints strewn throughout the game.Despite all of the above, this is quite simply one of the largest and most satisfying Metroidvania games I've ever played.  The maps are massive, the backstory is interesting and integrated into the puzzles.  The power-ups are fun, and the weapons provide enough variety to be satisfying without being numerous enough that any of them feel like afterthoughts.  In terms of content for the price, this game is an absolute steal.  If you have the chops for it, bring your action-platformer and adventure-game-puzzler A-games and take this one on right away.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												A great Metroidvania platformer with a good sense of boss design and challenge but poor conveyance on puzzles.Presentation:This is a standard 16 bit 2D graphics. Nothing technically special but the environments are based off designs of various cultures throughout the world. Enemies are based off some form of mythology. The bosses start off fairly intimidating then you encounter a satanic goat.The sound track is great and there's even a sound test within the game. There's a variety of instruments used.Story:You play an archelogist named Lemeza who tries to search for his father in the La Mulana Ruins. The lore of this game is found on ancient tablets and you piece together them to learn the history of this place.Lemenza is a silent protagonist but there are other characters that offer hints to you adventure but are still somewhat funny. There's the old man obsessed with video games and like to tell obvious lies that are funny because how blunt it is. Too bad every other character is just exposition or shopkeepers telling you to buy something.Gameplay:The controls are fine with keyboard but platforming is like Castlevania I on NES.Jumping while moving gives you little control in manuvering your jump, but standing still and jumping will pause you in place for a second and then given full control of you jump. This isn't too much of a problem espcially once you get the double jump. The worst part of the platforming is when you walk off a ledge. You lose any form of movement until you reach the ground. This can be really annoying since you will climb up long vertical shafts.You gain a large number of powerups and weapons that will help you through La Mulana. Weapons have different attack arcs that can help you hit certain enemies much easilly but you will probably stick with the whip with its hidden upgrades or the axe which has an excellent attack arc.There's also sub weapons that provides a ranged attack that run on individual ammo system that can be switched around easilly once you find them. Weapons range from surikens to a very expensive but deadly pistol.There's usable items that only serve the purpose of opening certain areas or reading tablets. There is one however that is very overpowered and can break nearly every sub boss.The powerups are fairly simple to increased HP or movement speed, but none of them really change the game except the double jump powerup.The last items you collect is computer software. Most of these items are either hidden or can bought in the store. They do various things like giving a map of the area granted you have the map of the place, or translate stone tablets. There's also hidden software combinations that cause special changes but you really don't know what it did.The normal enemies are good in variety but some are designed just to make platforming really annoying. There's a medusa head like enemy that shoots arrows at you. They also cause the Lemeza to have knockback which can be very annoying when platforming.Most sub bosses you encounter can be dispatched with full HP with little strategy and the ones that can't be dispatched either test your paitence or requires actual skill. The main bosses are all pretty challening but lack variety of moves. Once you learn to dodge them while still able to deal damage, then they are no problem.Outside of fighting and platforming are puzzles and secrets throughout the entire place of La Mulana Ruins. Now this is the biggest strength and its biggest flaw. Be prepared to take notes on stone tablets because those will be hints to puzzles in the zone you are or in a completely different area. Some of the tablets are pretty clever. However, some are just vague. There's one that requires you to pause the game in certain places. Then find a hidden warp pipe that leads to 4 tablets that gives vague one word hints.The amount of times I had to use a walkthrough is too much. Add some breakable/fake walls, or special hidden locks that can only be opened by a randomized summon. The good news is that the most vague puzzles are optional and miss nothing too major. There's still some ungodly hidden secrets you need to solve.If this game did not have puzzles, then it was still be a great game, but some puzzles are pretty good. There's great skill based obstacles you have to go through. This game still is very hard when it comes to combat.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												An 2D exploration-driven Metroidvania. The platforming and combat can be tricky. The rest of the game is much, much harder. Very well crafted, from the graphics to the action to the writing to the puzzles to the killer soundtrack,The exploration is very open-ended and organic feeling, which makes the world feel very real. It also means it's easy to venture into places you probably shouldn't be without realizing it. (a word of advice: DO NOT leave the first area before you get the Grail). Diving too deep will likely get you killed. But then again, going where you're supposed to go next can get you killed anyway. La Mulana is not a safe place.The puzzles and the story of the ruins are heavily interwoven. Bits of lore and puzzle hints are scattered everywhere, and the heart of the game is piecing it all together. Every puzzle has its solution implied somewhere, but percieving and understanding it may not happen on the first, or even the tenth, examination. The game starts hard and gets much harder, with the riddles, the hints, and the answers getting more esoteric as you progress, and spread over a much wider area of the ruins.That puzzle and progression design means that it's easy to have little idea what to do next. Am I supposed to be here? Does that tablet apply to this puzzle? Do I even have all of the items I need to complete it? Was I supposed to solve that other puzzle first? Multiply that uncertainty by 3, 4, 5 partially-explored areas on opposite ends of the ruins, and the confusion can quickly get overwhelming. If this sort of thing sounds terrible, La Mulana may not be for you, but the mechanics work wonderfully to enforce the mentality of exploring ancient, trap-filled, unforgiving ruins that nonetheless hide deep, deep secrets. That atmosphere is reinforced by stellar art direction and an excellent score (One of my top 5 VG soundtracks) You must be cautious, patient, thorough, willing to brave danger, and deeply dedicated to sifting through pieces of lost knowledge if you want to uncover just what lies in the depths of La Mulana.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Summary: La-Mulana is a massive Metroidvania game with smooth controls, beautiful environments, a great story, absolutely wonderful music, and ingenious puzzles that will take more than all your wit and luck to solve. But when your wit and skill pulls through for you and opens up the ruins further, you'll be rewarded with a true feeling of accomplishment.Review:This game will not hold your hand, period. You'll have to explore, find key items, and keep yourself alive by your own wit and skill. The clues scattered throughout the game are beyond numerous, and even if you write them all down, it'll take ingenuity and experimentation to decipher the meaning in the words, and figure out how that translates to an action to take in the game. Sometimes you'll even have to go the SOTN route and smack walls and floors in a blind hope of finding something (just be sure to check for eyes...). The most important key item in the entire game is easily missable, and is essentially required to explore the deeper parts of the ruins, as it allows you to teleport to save areas throughout. Traps and tough mini-bosses/bosses (which are all massive and wonderfully done) will kill you more than just a couple of times, and you'll just have to deal with it.My advice, explore as much as possible and gather clues rather than just sticking to one place. Clues don't always apply (in fact frequently they don't) to the area they are found in, and weapons/subweapons/power ups can be attained to help with issues you have with fights from other areas. Everyone will work through this game in their own order and pace when playing this game, and that's part of the beauty of it. Since you'll go in your own order though, a typical walkthrough will not be that helpful unless you read everything and spoil it for yourself. That being said, if you need help while playing, just hit the good old Shift + Tab and check out "The Cartographer's Guide to La-Mulana". It provides detailed maps of each area, including puzzle solutions and key items, while allowing you to focus your search to just the area you're having trouble with.Now I definitely can't say the puzzles are entirely "fair", but a large majority are. There were ~5-6 instances in this game where I was hopelessly lost, Shift + Tabbed, and after doing so, still didn't think any clue pointed to the solution (*cough* mario warp pipe nonsense *cough*). Particularly with the Hell Temple, I have no freaking clue how you could figure out how to unlock it on your own. The puzzles in the Hell Temple itself make sense (mostly), but the weird series of steps to unlock it are just ridiculous (funny, but ridiculous).Also, I know I didn't go into detail, but the music in this game is freaking awesome. I mean it, some of the best ever for the genre of game. Blend up some Megaman X & Castlevania and be drawn into it.On sale, this game is a steal. Buy it and have fun, get totally lost, and one way or another, reach the end.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												One of the all-great retro platformers. La-Mulana derives it's inspiration from world mythology, Indiana Jones and most of all, old MSX games. As you progress in the game, the game expands greatly on all fronts. The deceptively simple game mechanics are built upon layer upon layer, the levels get larger and more complex, the bosses get bigger and badder, the mythology and lore gets more and more elaborate.. and knowing it will become necessary to solve some of the most fiendishly difficult puzzles ever seen in a platformer. Still, the game does not resort to unfairness. Every challenge is surmountable, no enemy is invulnerable, and every puzzle has a hint somewhere. At least, until the mythical Hell Temple. But then again, that place is designed for people who want to prevail against all odds. Everyone else can expect 30ish ours of best platforming that you can hope to get.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I prefer metroidvania's in comparison to most other games. There's the feeling of exploration that you don't get from other genres, an air of freedom that's restricted only by your equipment and skill, the challenge of reaching something new that's mere inches over the tower of angry crazed monstrocities that haven't tasted food in centuries, just waiting for you to slip... It's amazing.La Mulana definitely met what I was looking for. It's a scarilly difficult game, but it's fantastic. If you're willing to brave the countless monsters lurking around the ruins, and smart enough to outwit the builders of these crazy traps and puzzles, this game is for you. There's treasure to be found, people to help, and a mess of bosses and sub-bosses that will have you rattling the controller in rage... in a good way. The game is beyond the simple word "challenging", which is flung around too often these days.Be warned though, brute force is NOT the answer to the majority of puzzles. You have to be smart with this game. Bosses themselves are a puzzle of what is safe, and what... isn't. And believe me, if you make a mistake with bosses, the all too common game over screen should be enough to tell you to try something else. If in doubt, look to the manual on the website. If that's not enough, there's no shame in looking to a guide. This game, in a few cases, demands it.

												I've only had an hour of  La-Mulana  and I already feel like other people need to experience it.I feel like divulging information that I've discovered in-game breaches some kind of unwritten rules of the game that makes it more fun for newer players. La-Mulana  has some of the things I loved so much about  Dark Souls  in how difficulty is managed. If you're in an area that you're not ready for, you'll know.While this game does have a pause menu, it still feels tense. The realization that you can't just hide in your e-mails until all        the  spooky scary    skeletons go away is kind of  refreshing.While the translations probably simplify the dialogues and descriptions in-game, they're fun to read and are, in a surprisingly interesting way, loosely educational in places.It also makes me want to stand, fully-clothed, in some hot springs.If that's not a success, I don't know what is.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												La-Mulana focuses heavily on riddles and exploring inside a gigantic ruin. Some of these puzzles can be quite difficult to solve, but then you really feel you accomplished something. But even if you feel stuck, just go to another area, as many parts of the ruins can be accessed from the beginning. Others can be reached by obtaining certain items.There's a lot of different items, main and sub weapons to be found, each serving a certain purpose. So this gets elevated to a Metroidvania-style game.You even do not have to fight the bosses in a fixed order to progress. As for those boss battles, these are varied as well: There are stationary ones, in one fight you ride a track down in a mine-cart, while the foe follows you.Awesome.My only gripe in the game is some very obscure hints for certain puzzles. You probably might have to look up somewhere or trying out a lot there - but be assured, there so much to do in the game, You will never feel bad, if you 'cheated' after you clocked so many hours into the game already. Just check that thing in a suspicious room further (or go somewhere else, as stated above) and move on your own.The controls themselves are solid and work as intended. Only jumping down below properly needs some practice first. Lemeza falls straight down, if he doesn't jump from a cliff, unable to change direction. Luckily there is no fall damage and many regular enemies only do little damage, except for some sub and main bosses.Take a hop before jumping on platforms below you - and you can move Lemeza in mid-air. Required for certain puzzles and just being a small hint.I play the game with a keyboard by the way, while the game has full controller support, including XBOX360 support as in the dscription, and there's no problem with controlling that way as well.The Graphics are really well done. They are stretched in fullscreen, the aspect ratio is mantainted properly. In widescreen formats the black bars can be decorated with murals and other images by going into the Options menu - which is a nice touch. Each ruin is vastly different, many background objects and statues are unique (and often required to be examined further by the game). There's even a hidden area, where you explore some of the original areas with the MSX-style graphics from the 2005 version.Music and sound are nicely done as well. While the tracks might repeat too quickly, many of the areas (in my case, e. g. the Temple of Moonlight) have catchy background music, some more decent, others being more dominant. For anyone who likes videogame music, this might be just right. The sound effects help you, be it a breakable wall which makes a certain crumble noise if struck by (certain) weapons, different tunes whenever you fail or solve a puzzle and other effects.If you don't mind the difficulty at times and love either cool boss battles and some brain-teasing puzzles, get this game ASAP. It's worth every penny, especially at that bargain in this sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												IN SHORT: A very difficult game in the tradition of NES Metroid and Castlevania.Within the last year or so I learned the term "Metroidvania" and it seems like it was made for this game.  Gameplay reminds me a lot of the original Metroid, and then you're whipping skeletons just like Castlevania.I guess I was warned, but this is a hard game.  As if fighting your way through the ruins wasn't hard enough already there are hidden booby traps (frustrating, but adds a fun new element as well).I love the mix of cultural artifacts from around the world you see, and I like the story of the Mother Goddess who created the Earthly races in hopes they could return her to the heavens--and who periodically kills them off when they anger her.You find lots of clues on stone tablets (which may apply to something you'll find in a whole different area).  In theory it'd be fun to piece together the story like this, but I've found them more difficult to understand and sort of generic sounding (this is probably do in part to the translation from Japanese).I've made some progress (defeated one boss) and am hoping I can get past the difficulty factor and really get into this game, but it's possible I might give up.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Some warnings up-front: this game can be hard to get into.  The controls aren't explained well initially, and it takes time to get a feel for the platforming mechanics, which are fairly idiosyncratic.  It's not an easy game either; it pulls very few punches and is much stingier than most modern games about checkpoint placement and health recovery.  There are also several fairly tough puzzles that require some creative interpretation of the sometimes-badly-translated hints strewn throughout the game.Despite all of the above, this is quite simply one of the largest and most satisfying Metroidvania games I've ever played.  The maps are massive, the backstory is interesting and integrated into the puzzles.  The power-ups are fun, and the weapons provide enough variety to be satisfying without being numerous enough that any of them feel like afterthoughts.  In terms of content for the price, this game is an absolute steal.  If you have the chops for it, bring your action-platformer and adventure-game-puzzler A-games and take this one on right away.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												So, I picked up this game cause it was on sale a while back and decided "Why not?", and unlike most things I happen to get on a whim, this game happened to be a real treasure.  Starting off though, I HIGHLY recommend a Gamepad of sorts for this game. I can only imagine going through this game with a Keyboard would make one want to Chuck it out the window. If you do NOT have a Gamepad, some of the platforming will be quite difficult assuming you are too used to platforming like elements with a controller as I was. Also the jumping physics take some getting used to.Gameplay: The gameplay is as other people have called it "Metroidvania" Wheras the game is centered around these large ruins and have seperate areas within the ruins that define as "other levels" So, in a nut shell, you go around the ruins exploring, trying to figure out what purpose these ruins have or what mysteries you can unfold. The more you discover, the more items you unlock, thus allowing access to different areas of the ruins.Difficulty: Wow, there are parts in this game where it makes you wanna rage, but if you're like me, and enjoy a challenege. It's all in good fun. You cannot heal yourself by normal means, you have to either go to the hotspring outside the ruins, or collect enough green orbs to "Level up"      The puzzles in this game are quite clever ranging from block destrcution order to in game ciphers. Though there are puzzles as simple as placing a weight on a pedestal (or dias as called in this game) So, there is a large degree of puzzle difficulty variation in this game. (Protip: No hint is too small in this game)     The bosses.. holy crap. Their moveset may not be very extensive, but they are very unforgiving. There are 9 Main bosses in this game. The first one being... generally easy, but after that, it's no cakewalk. These bosses generally take a degree of skill to defeat. If you die, you have to start all the way back from your last quick save. It's usually not THAT far of a walk, though there is this one area where its just annoying.. gotta wait for elevators... and suicidal fish.. just a bad experience, but made one feel so accomplished after finally taking care of the foul boss for that victorious fanfare after defeating a boss.Music: The Music in this game is quite amazing I think. Not really much else to say.Storyline: Kind of non-existant untill about halfway through the game. There's slight lore on each area of the ruins, but once you reach that halfway mark and the lore starts to tie into each other, It becomes clear that there is MUCH more to the ruins than one could have initially thought of. I love it.  Category Rating   Gameplay 8   Soundtrack 9   Story 7   Difficulty 8   Overall 8-9 Overall, This game's got alot of good things going for it, music, story, memorable characters. It's difficulty and obscure puzzles may deter other gamers, but I enjoy the challenge. Pick up this game if you enjoy one as well!! You won't regret it.

												This is the true Indiana Jones simulator. Combining exploration, action, platforming and puzzle solving, La-Mulana is a long and hard but truely satisfying game. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I love this game. Even after almost 6 hours I've only found and defeated one boss, but I rarely feel like I'm wandering around aimlessly. I feel like I'm gathering clues to solve a huge puzzle...and most of the time that's exactly what I'm doing. Every time I backtrack I find something new, or decipher a cryptic note I didn't understand the last time. It's like a tougher and more puzzle-oriented Super Metroid with some I Wanna Be The Guy-style traps. Hints come in the form of emails from the village elder as well, but they're not too revealing, just a little nudge to help you get going. Expect to be writing some things down on your journey. My only complaint is the controls, which I suppose are supposed to be realistic, but even after 6 hours I'm still not used to them. When you jump you're committed to it; forward jumping has a set arc depending on how high you jump that can't be interrupted, and jumping straight up is uncontrollable until you reach the height of the jump. Falling off a ledge forces you to plummet straight down. It's somewhat irritating at times, but it's tolerable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												The game starts off great. It gives you clues on how to progress and vague goals. I've got a little notebook by my computer, and it's been fun to write down the clues I get and writing notes, it feels like actual exploration in a way I've never seen in a game before. But, uh.Remember that part in Super Metroid where you get the power bomb and wander around for a couple hours trying to figure out what to do wih it? And then you finally manage to blow up the glass tube that gets you in Maridia, and you think to yourself, "How on earth was I supposed to know to do that?"Yeah. Welcome to that, the videogame. The middle to end of this game is effectively that, repeatedly, for a number of hours. Rather than difficulty, the game goes straight into obscurity. The clues go from helpful to extremely vague and start making sense only after the fact ("...Oh, /that/'s what that meant.") You'll (sometimes) have a vague sense of what needs to be done - or rather, a collection of things that /can/ be done, though whether or not you're actually able to do them yet is unknown - and no idea how to do them or where to get them. It stops giving you goals on what you're supposed to be doing, removes any feeling of progression, and the game boils down to revisiting every area over and over and over again in the vague hope of finding something new. And when you do find something new, the experience is fleeting, because the new trinket or path or whatever it gives you is usually in another part of the game, wildly far from you.TL;DR: unless you are a masochist with rediculous amounts of free time and patience, you will need a walkthrough for this game at some point. The level design does not guide you along at all, and is actively obtrusive. The difficulty changes from basic survival to constantly trying figuring out the developer's logic like you're playing an old Lucas Arts point-and-click from back in the day. Granted that may apppeal to some of you; the game does not hold your hand, especially mid and onwards, and there can be value in that.All that said, I'm still going to buy La Mulana 2 when it comes out, because at the end of the day, the game is still fun to me.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
One fool believed, in his foolishness, that he was a wise man. The fool flaunted his shallow wisdom and made decisions with a narrow mind. He proceeded to the right without hesitation.  Another fool possessed wisdom, but his knowledge led him to believe he was a fool. A fool who smothers himself without first considering the situation. He went with the flow, and proceeded to the left.One can only hope that a true wise man stands here now. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------La-Mulana is not for the faint of heart or weak of mind. This is NOT a game where you can grind until you're strong enough to win. This is NOT a game where you can skip the lore and expect to succeed. And this is most certainly NOT a game where you can expect an easy victory just because you looked up the puzzle solutions online.Despite what my Steam records say, I've beaten this game twice now. (First the original, then a non-Steam release of this remake.) And neither time was easy in the slightest. You want fun? Play this. You want bland tedium that will atrophy your brain? Play your Call of Warbattles or Flappy Crush.La-Mulana is more than a video game; It's a test of character.(Soapboxing aside, I have to point out that the Linux version seems kinda janky. Just a warning.)--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Those who do not listen, do not make light of the words of others. To come so far, blinded by pride at thine own powers... thou art a true fool. A fool deserves naught but death.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 10, 2013
												Imagine a metroidvania, but with a thick layer of varnish spread all over it. Progressing in La Milon's Secret Castle relies on mastering both the unforgiving jumping physics and extremely obtuse puzzles. The real draw of the game is, the underlying lore and story are closely linked to the puzzles for the most part via reading of tablets covered in cryptic text and primitive drawings where you can almost see the self-satisfied smug of the developer who drew them. Enemies are largely slow-moving piles of hitbox, whereas bosses are piles of hitbox that take up half of the screen. The weapons you're saddled with are just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ enough to make the proceedings fairly challenging.Through the end of all of this suffering and turmoil the rewards definitely await, with no shortage of Chicken McItems you can get your greasy fingers on. If you can take the time to read all the tablets, discern what area the hint originated from, what particular puzzle or setpiece the hint is actually referring to, and cross-reference this information in the same notebook for which you keep track of your Zoloft medication, you clearly deserve this game.One thing I can attest is that this game helped me reignite the rage within my heart. At times a vein erupts in my forehead, I rip off my shirt and start beating my chest wildly, and it eventually takes 3 social workers and a powerful horse sedative to restrain me. 9/10 game, tell your friends.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
One fool believed, in his foolishness, that he was a wise man. The fool flaunted his shallow wisdom and made decisions with a narrow mind. He proceeded to the right without hesitation.  Another fool possessed wisdom, but his knowledge led him to believe he was a fool. A fool who smothers himself without first considering the situation. He went with the flow, and proceeded to the left.One can only hope that a true wise man stands here now. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------La-Mulana is not for the faint of heart or weak of mind. This is NOT a game where you can grind until you're strong enough to win. This is NOT a game where you can skip the lore and expect to succeed. And this is most certainly NOT a game where you can expect an easy victory just because you looked up the puzzle solutions online.Despite what my Steam records say, I've beaten this game twice now. (First the original, then a non-Steam release of this remake.) And neither time was easy in the slightest. You want fun? Play this. You want bland tedium that will atrophy your brain? Play your Call of Warbattles or Flappy Crush.La-Mulana is more than a video game; It's a test of character.(Soapboxing aside, I have to point out that the Linux version seems kinda janky. Just a warning.)--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Those who do not listen, do not make light of the words of others. To come so far, blinded by pride at thine own powers... thou art a true fool. A fool deserves naught but death.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
												This game is really, really good. I cheated and played the game with a guide, and *still* had an amazing time with it, and even played the game a couple more times. It's one of the best games ever made. I'm dead serious.The game has fantastic music, amazing boss fights, and a huge expansive world with an incredibly deep lore. However, the game is full of extremely cryptic puzzles.Honestly, I recommend that you play this game until you get stuck, then go through the rest of it with a walkthrough. Some of the puzzles in this game are just not reasonable, and it's impossible to tell in advance the difference between reasonable puzzles, unreasonable puzzles, and puzzles you can't solve yet. It is also extremely non-linear, which complicates matters.If you want to beat this game without help, I recommend against it, but here's my advice. There's very little in the game that is blatantly not hinted at, but many of the hints are extremely cryptic. Get a notepad and write down every single hint you come across (or screenshot them). And don't come into it with the attitude that you're going to clear one area at a time; after the initial Gate of Guidance, you have to hop back and forth between areas frequently to progess. Many of the puzzles require out-of-the-box thinking so be ready for that. Read the manual and watch the Beginner's Guide. This game is tough as nails, and beating it is a project. Expect it to take hundreds of hours (if you use a guide, 10 hours). This is a real game.For my friends, I love this game, and I know it inside and out, so if you want me to hint you in the right direction instead of resorting to a guide, I'm happy to talk about it any time.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I love this game. Even after almost 6 hours I've only found and defeated one boss, but I rarely feel like I'm wandering around aimlessly. I feel like I'm gathering clues to solve a huge puzzle...and most of the time that's exactly what I'm doing. Every time I backtrack I find something new, or decipher a cryptic note I didn't understand the last time. It's like a tougher and more puzzle-oriented Super Metroid with some I Wanna Be The Guy-style traps. Hints come in the form of emails from the village elder as well, but they're not too revealing, just a little nudge to help you get going. Expect to be writing some things down on your journey. My only complaint is the controls, which I suppose are supposed to be realistic, but even after 6 hours I'm still not used to them. When you jump you're committed to it; forward jumping has a set arc depending on how high you jump that can't be interrupted, and jumping straight up is uncontrollable until you reach the height of the jump. Falling off a ledge forces you to plummet straight down. It's somewhat irritating at times, but it's tolerable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												Probably one of the best games I've ever played as well as one of the hardest.Action-wise... the game is tough but fair.  The standard enemies are not a terrible threat, but they'll wear you down over time if you're not careful.  The bosses are quite challenging, require practice to beat, but many of them can be made easier by outscaling them with power-ups.The puzzles though... Oh god... Mercy... I thought I was doing pretty well at first, but after getting about a third of the way into the game, I was stuck.  This game is full of "moon logic" puzzles.  Even if you are very meticulous in taking notes, you'll likely need to refer to a guide to get through much of the game.  These aren't optional puzzles either, they're REQUIRED to complete the game.  You could wander for hours, whipping walls and trying things and still not find out where you need to go next.  The game puts in all the necessary clues to solving the puzzles on stone tablets scattered throughout the world, but  knowing which clue relates to which puzzle is a feat in and of itself.A single playthrough will take you a bit over 20 hours... that's all "productive" time.  If you include time spent dying/losing progress from dying, you'll probably be closer to 60+ hours.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												La-Mulana is a 2d exploration-based platformer, a metroidvania, if you will. You run around a vast interconnected complex of ruins, whipping snakes and skeletons and bats and whatnot, solving puzzles, jumping, falling on spikes, etc. There are many little treasures to collect, powering up your character in some small way, often in such a way that is only really necessary for accessing a single area of the labyrinth, but giving you an actual ability rather than just throwing a key in your hand is a nice touch. The puzzles are many and quite esoteric, which I appreciate, though a few too many of them simply force you to return with some gadget, that more than likely required some other thing to solve its own puzzle. It definitely walks the line between intellectually engaging and tedious. The music is good. Overall the game has a lot of personality, doing things that seem a bit absurd from a design standpoint, but ultimately contributing to that intimate, programmed in somebody's mom's basement kind of feel that make Indie games the joy they are. Or can be, anyway. Where the game falls flat on its face is combat. Wonky collision, tedious enemies, needlessly frustrating bosses, pointless sub weapons, unresponsive controls, obnoxious healing mechanics, it's difficult to name something that was done right in terms of the combat design. The combat and platforming draw heavily, if not entirely, from NES era Castlevania. The whip has a little delay on it, your jump arc can't be altered (much) after you've left the ground, getting hit sends you flyiing, there are subweapons that, hypothetically at least, can fill in the gaps in your offensive capabillities. And that may have worked, if the level and enemy design had been borrowed from NES Catlevania as well. Instead, You find yourself navigating post-Symphony of the Night levels and enemies with pre-Symphony of the Night controls. Enemies move around a lot and in fairly random patterns, hitting them without getting hit yourself is a bit of a gamble (there's a very good reason fleamen only took one hit in Castlevania). You'll routinely find yourself knowcked off platforms and faced with a lengthy trek to return simply because a bat decided to move a certain way at a certain time. Many enemies are simply a matter of sitting and waiting for them to turn their back so you can hit them wothout risking your life (waiting is not skill). The subweapons are slow, weak, and generally go in a straight line, which begs the question of why there are even so many. It uses a bizarre healing mechanic. Enemies drop little health balls, but instead of restoring your health, they fill a bar underneath your health and then, once that bar is filled , all your health. This virtually guarantees that your health will be restored at some arbitrary moment, rather than when you would could actually benefit. Why the balls don't just restore your health directly is beyond me. The system can only be described as asinine. All of this would be tolerable, but what truly sinks the ship are the disastrous boss battles. Don't get me wrong, graphically the bosses are very impressive. Detailed, well animated, room-filling sprites certainly have an appeal about them. But the problem is that a massive room filling monstrosity has to be able to fight the player in such a way that justifies that level of detail. When, for all the charging and fire breath and crumbly cieling bits, the main threat, the biggest factor driving the difficulty of the fight, is not anything the boss is actually doing, but the difficulty inherent in negotiating the tiny area from which you can hit the boss without getting hit yourself, all that detail becomes a bit pointless. For a boss to attack the player in however many unique and interesting ways, but ultimately kill them because the player touched its chin a few too many times shows very bad combat design. I'm going to go farther and say that the concept of the player being hurt by touching enemies is an archaic anachronism and should be done away with. But whatever. Yeah, the game is hard. Hard in a very Dark Souls kind of way, where it's not really so much that you need to get good at it, but that you need to remember stuff and proceed slowly and not break your controller and all that noise. It's punishing and clunky and sort of poorly designed on purpose to make it more difficult. Sometimes that can be nice. I recommend it despite it's flaws. I dunno, play it or don't. It's unique, I respect that.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												La-Mulana's close to being a perfect game. It sure as hell is a perfect Action-Adventure Platforming Puzzle Game.LM sets out to be a game all about exploration and achieves this by making large areas that are enjoyable, challenging, and interesting to explore. All the while, items that can augment your skills and aid in your exploration are scattered throughout. Often times you can see these items but you'll have to solve difficult puzzles along the way to open them, thus creating great tension and lead up. Once you have these items, the effects are immediately noticible from running/attacking faster to something as simple as opening doors that used to be locked. Every pair of areas also have enjoyable(?), challenging, and interesting boss battles, following the same rules of puzzle solving and lead up as items do. It's incredibly easy to get immersed into the world of La-Mulana, and if you have the guts to stick it through the challenge, La-Mulana will reward you.That said, the game is floaty and the PC has very little control of their jumping (like Castlevania), on top of that, knockback can often lead to slow painful death (not like Castlevania). While this was done intentionally for the sake of difficulty - which works - it can be overly punishing for more casual players. While this is by no means a casual game, it's difficult to have fun when you can't continue exploring. Puzzles also become more and more complex and outright insane later in. I recommend having pulling out a walkthrough around that part, the alternative is pulling out your hair. Sadly this makes the later segments of the game drag on as the puzzles become larger and more complex. Though still important, it involves a lot of backtracking through obnoxious sections of the game.But those complaints are partially personal. La-Mulana is an amazing game with great length, and is strong enough to withstand multiple playthroughs. If you don't mind the challenge, I heartily recommend La-Mulana at its full price. If you're a cheapscape like I am, then I recommend La-Mulana at less than full price but if you want to play La-Mulana and still don't when that happens then you are an awful awful person who I will never invite to my birthday party ever again. And I'll probably kill you before you pass your inferior genes to a new generation. In either case you won't be getting any cake.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 6, 2013
												La-Mulana is a Legend of Tetrisvania style action exploration game with a whip cracking good soundtrack. You play as Indianus Sphincter Jones, or Lemeza for short, an archaeological digging teacher professor who is searching the ancient ruins of La-Mulana for his heart, which was stolen by the crimson dragon, Eddie Murphy, forever marking him as an Arisen.For some reason though, La-Mulana isn't ruined when you purchase it.The gameplay is like strangling a sock with a hot dog. You start out with a small bar of health that increases as you collect these items called Sacred Orbs. I'd have low health too if I didn't have my orbs. As you progress through the various traps and transexuals of La-Mulana, you're obviously going to be taking damage. The only way to heal is to eat these snot bubbles that enemies drop, or to give a load off in the hot springs.You could say that the level design is pretty PUZZLING. Picture Ghouls n Ghosts and throw all of its hundreds of puzzles into a bag, and put La-Mulana's puzzles into a bag and all of a sudden they becomePerhaps the greatest feature is your character's progression. You can really feel your chips begin to sog when you're wailing on bosses you had trouble with before but you can't fight bosses you've already killed you idiot.Overall, La-Mulana is a pretty great musical. With stars like Hugh Jackman and Bob Ross, you get an amazing visual of the jungle.I give it about ten high fives.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I love this game. Even after almost 6 hours I've only found and defeated one boss, but I rarely feel like I'm wandering around aimlessly. I feel like I'm gathering clues to solve a huge puzzle...and most of the time that's exactly what I'm doing. Every time I backtrack I find something new, or decipher a cryptic note I didn't understand the last time. It's like a tougher and more puzzle-oriented Super Metroid with some I Wanna Be The Guy-style traps. Hints come in the form of emails from the village elder as well, but they're not too revealing, just a little nudge to help you get going. Expect to be writing some things down on your journey. My only complaint is the controls, which I suppose are supposed to be realistic, but even after 6 hours I'm still not used to them. When you jump you're committed to it; forward jumping has a set arc depending on how high you jump that can't be interrupted, and jumping straight up is uncontrollable until you reach the height of the jump. Falling off a ledge forces you to plummet straight down. It's somewhat irritating at times, but it's tolerable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												How to describe La-Mulana?La-Mulana is oldschool.  It does not hold your hand.  It does not pull its punches.  It is not aftaid to dish out instant death as a concequence for failure.  This is a hard game, though for the most part it's a fair kind of hard.  Still, not for the faint of heart, or those unwilling to actually solve a few puzzles.  Even the jump physics will punish you at first (this isn't the air control you're used to) and you need to master most aspects of the game if you want to have a chance.The good news, for those who find this a little daunting?  La-Mulana is not Nethack or Zork.  If you die (and you will), you'll be able to restart from your latest save or, pretty shortly, even from a checkpoint.  If you see something that's trouble and think "I should really save before doing this." you can generally save before doing it, and there are few if any true lost-forever items (though there are more that become very difficult to attain, or can't be got for a long while if you mess up.)  So, while you will be punished for messing up, you're generally free to take your beating, burning, squashing, impalement upon spikes, heavenly lightning, or so on and keep playing, only now you know better.  In this way it is more of a modern Metroid/Castlevania type "explore and platform" game than a roguelike or adventure game relative, since you're generally not going to be in danger of losing more than minutes of work.In general, I'd recommend anyone who has a chance to try it give it a go.  I've focused on its difficulty and mechanics, but I shouldn't fail to say that it is a ton of fun.  There's a lot to find -- story as well as items and areas -- the visuals are great oldschool art that frankly looks great on its own, and the gameplay is an experience with a very rewarding learning curve.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 31, 2013
												La-Mulana is a Metroidvania style game where you play as a Japanese take on Indiana Jones as you adventure to and explore the ruins of La-Mulana, the origin of all mankind in this world. There are plenty of puzzles and traps to see in the ruins that will keep you on your toes, this is also perhaps also one of the games faults as you WILL be doing look ups on walktroughs to break some of the game's more challenging puzzles. If you haven't had to look up a solution by the time you reach the Gate of Illision, you will then. The combat and movement is very finely tuned, not too often did I feel that my death was unjustified, it was usually due to my own lack of skill or even missing critical equipment for an encounter. Movement is pretty smooth even though you lack movement mid-jump, even after learning how to double jump. Upon recovering the Hooly Grail after solving a few simple puzzles in the enterance of La-Mulana you will gain the ability to teleport between save points from anywhere inside this sprawling dungeon.Health recovery in this game is a little strange, you recover your HP by sitting on hot springs or by collecting enough EXP from green orbs dropped by foes to equal the full length of your health bar upon which your EXP will be reset to 0 and your HP will be fully restored to %100 reguardless of how much health you have at the time. With this health recoverly system you wThe lore you will discover in the ruins paint an interesting spin on the origin of mankind and even how mankind ends in the La-Mulana world. This game is genininely worth a look and I highly reccomend it.

Posted: July 21, 2013
												This game answers the question "What would the original Metroid be like if there was any rhyme or reason to the puzzles?" The player is almost forced to keep a notebook to stay on top of the clues: the difficulty is mainly derived not from impossibly boss battles or jumps with a pixel-wide margin of error, but rather from the riddles that must be solved to progress. 99% of the solutions to the  puzzles that stumped me (which I was forced to look up) made me go "Ahhhh, I see how I should have figured that out." A must play for gamers for whom Cave Story mixed with 7th Guest seems like it might be fun.

												La-Mulana is a pretty good game, but it's definitively not for everyone. There is a huge focus on puzzle solving and it's not the easy kind which you often find in other games *coughzeldacough*. When it works well it works really well, but a couple of puzzles are really obtuse in what you need to do to solve them, this can be a problem when you get further into the game as the explorable space just gets larger and larger.The platforming and combat is also pretty good for the most part, there are a few hiccups, but nothing major. So if you want a game that really pulls of the concept of you being an archaeologist uncovering the truth/legends of an ancient ruin, then I honestly can't think of any other game that gets even close to that when compared to La-Mulana.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Hours don't matter; I beat the game via a GOG.com versionAnyway, this game is amazing. Some of the best bosses I've seen in a metroidvania, outstanding music, an amazing final boss and a perfect escape sequence. The story is surprisingly deep with lore everywhere ala Metroid Prime, and the game is very long, easily lasting tens of hours.With that said, USE A GUIDE.Don't think you can get away with playing this game blind, unless you're a VERY determined player. You will have to write down nearly everything you scan, explore whatever you can, etc. This game is ridiculous in puzzles and level design and, in my opinion, it's nowhere near to even the best part of the game! It's well worth skipping it using a guide because the rest of the game IS worth it. Items, powerups, etc really help alleviate the difficulty this game has at the beginning.Also, this game is pretty hard even with a guide. For a good portion of the game you have no defense and very bad platforming; it gets much better later, but if you don't have a guide for powerups, it's understandable how you can get frustrated because the tools to make your life easier aren't available. However, at about the half-way point the game becomes much more tolerable due to the sheer amount of abilities you have gotten. Also, it is worth mentioning that both whip upgrades are permanently missable; however, reloading a save can let you try again. Just keep that in mind. With that said, the game is amazing. In my own experience, it's an 8/10 for the first half and a 10/10 for the second half, but only with a guide. Highly recommended, just, make sure you know what you are getting into.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												La-Mulana pleasantly surprised me when I first started playing.  Here was a Metroidvania in the strictest sense of the word, with an expansive hand-crafted map just waiting to be explored.  Pivotal items could be found anywhere, so you were constantly rewarded for investigating every nook and cranny.  These upgrades also allowed you to intuitively access new areas--for example, once you acquire an item that lets you breathe underwater, you can progress further in a watery area.At this point, my only complaints were that save points are few and far between, and are often not located anywhere near bosses.As I progressed through the game, I grew more and more frustrated.  Upgrades stopped being intuitive since the obstacles they got past became too obviously artificial.  For example, some items interact with arbitrary symbols found throughout the ruins, which you had no reason to believe were important at all.  This leads to a lot of directionless backtracking.Eventually, I got stuck, looked at a guide, and was shocked at the number of required items that were hidden in unfairly obscure locations.  Stuff like "once you do X, a ceiling in an unrelated area that you've already explored becomes breakable with your whip".  Maybe a tablet somewhere contains a subtle hint that would point you in the right direction, but I feel this level of opaqueness is bad game design.  Super Metroid had plenty of hidden secrets, but there was almost always something unusual about the area to prompt you to scan it more closely with your X-Ray Scope.I'm unsure whether I will continue playing La-Mulana, but if I do, I expect to have to rely on a guide.  Despite this, I do see why the game was so influential, and I still think it has quite a lot to offer.

												This one is controversial... yet, it is an adventure gem. Up to a mid-game it plays brilliantly - full of exploration, character, discovery, figuring out what to do next. Bosses are somewhat on a grindy side of the moon (pixel accuracy madness). Somewhere in mid-game (you'll know when it happens) the only recommendation is - forget it :-) It is more of design flaws and pixel accuracy of latter bosses that break the flow then anything else (alternatively you can use FAQ)... But two components which still make this game a gem for me (and practically all other games miss) are there - exploration and discovery. Just wish design choices were more player-friendly in otherwise great game...A tip: buy this on-sale, so you won't regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Some things the original does better. Some things this remake does better. If you're at all interested in a game that will not hold your hand, has actual puzzles that require thought and detailed scanning of the ruins, has challenging but fair fights, then I implore you to try the free version for a feel of what the remake has to offer. Oh, if you're afraid of being punished for your mistakes you can just get out now.You can find everything you need to get started here: http://agtp.romhack.net/project.php?id=lamulanaRunning the original version on modern windows require some finangling in the compatability settings, but it's fairly straightforward (Run as admin, compatability mode for XP service pack 2, 16-bit color mode.)That being said, what this version offers over the original is a more streamlined experience. Some of the puzzles were switched out and brand new ones even thrown in. This updated version is a lot less obtuse. While I hated the new graphics at first, they certainly grew on me and it was nice to hear some of the songs in a modernized format.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												This game is not as difficult as others have said....La-Mulana is an homage to the older adventure games of the NES era. Castlevania, Battle of Olympus, and Faxanadu all rolled into one great little package. Just like the games of yester-year, La-Mulana does not hold your hand. It is up to the player to remember all the little details that add up later. To be able to find the hidden entrances that others in a hurry might miss. This game is about the fine details, covering every inch of every room to find your way! If you enjoy a solid challenge, and a grand adventure (with a little naughty mixed in), La-Mulana awaits!!
